DUNCAN MCLEAN

LECTURER AT THE AUSTRALIAN FILM TELEVISION AND RADIO SCHOOL AND REVIEWER AT DOCTOR OF MOVIES.

Ten best (alphabetical order)

Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) (Alejandro González Iñárritu, 2014)

An entirely original cinematic vision. So much more than a single shot gimmick. Complete unity of form and content.

Creed (Ryan Coogler, 2015)

Sometimes a film gives you something you didn’t even know that you wanted. Coogler’s fresh take on Rocky was the pleasant surprise of the year.

Ex Machina (Alex Garland, 2015)

Great small science fiction. A well performed chamber piece which draws its drama out of conversations and dialogue.

Inherent Vice (Paul Thomas Anderson, 2014)

A humorous and enjoyable head-scratcher that definitely requires multiple viewings. Finally The Big Lebowski has a friend in the “stoner noir” sub-genre.

Inside Out (Pete Docter and Ronnie Del Carmen, 2015)

While not their best film, arguably the zenith of Pixar’s bold originality.

Listen to Me, Marlon (Stevan Riley, 2015)

A unique documentary befitting a unique talent. An intimate exploration of a brilliant but tortured soul which amounts to a posthumous autobiography.

Mad Max: Fury Road (George Miller, 2015)

George Miller took the world’s directors to school and showed how a singular creative vision can elevate the action film to the level of high art.

The Martian (Ridley Scott, 2015)

Ridley Scott’s return to form. An enjoyable, funny and absorbing film that excites you more with its intellect and ideas than with explosions.

Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (Alfonso Gomez-Rejon, 2015)

A beautifully affecting piece of cinema brimming with youthful creativity. A special movie.

Selma (Ava DuVernay, 2014)

The year’s most powerful biopic, which unfortunately remains as thematically relevant as ever.

Probably the worst year ever – but not in cinema. The avant-garde may not be what it used to be, but in a year of countless horrors there is at least some sort of relief in looking back at some of the films that stood out by standing up for the creative and critical freedom of artistic imagination. The Senses of Cinema poll is an occasion to invent awards for 10 of the best.

With its ethical undertone on the themes of artificial intelligence, Ex Machina certainly has the potential of becoming a sci-fi cult classic. Mad Max: Fury Road (George Miller, 2015)

While fourth instalments of film series often show signs of some serious issues with the franchise, Fury Road revives the Mad Max series and propels it into the 21st Century with all guns blazing in one of the most entertaining sci-fi action blockbusters in recent memory. With subtle environmental undertones that echo George Miller’s previous work, there is also enough substance to make repeat viewings a joy. Top ten in UK cinemas 2015 (alphabetical order)

Rak ti Khon Kaen (Cemetery of Splendour, Apichatpong Weerasethakul, 2015)

Screened at the London Film Festival in October this marked the end of an era in contemporary film. Joe claims this to be his last (feature) film made in Thailand and it serves as a wonderful climax and summation of themes explored in his cinema to date. A sublime waking dream.

Jauja (Lisandro Alonso, 2014)

Released in limited UK cinemas in the spring, this Herzogian head trip around historical and cinematic memory expanded on the director’s previous approach to everyday realism and skewed narrative.

Jia Zhangke, um homem de Fenyang (Jia Zhangke, a Guy from Fenyang, Walter Salles, 2015)

Touching portrait of the Chinese filmmaker screened at LFF 2015. Captures the essence of Jia’s cinema with intelligence and warmth as the director visits the locales of his upbringing. A timely definition of how cinema and the artist’s life cannot be separated.

Heaven’s Will (Li Pengfei, 2015)

Screened at the Chinese Visual Festival 2015 over the summer, this independent documentary told the story of a charismatic former gangster who starts to correctly predict the death of his village’s inhabitants.

Cavalo Dinheiro (Horse Money, Pedro Costa, 2014)

Universally raved by critics, Costa is now a leading voice in the uncompromised auteur based art cinema. The latest is a nocturnal stroll around the mental prisons of the damaged and disenfranchised Cape Verdean immigrants of Lisbon. An almost surrealist prologue to the twin epics In Vanda’s Room and Colossal Youth.

Love (Gaspar Noé, 2015)

Noé continues to be a hypnotically engaging filmmaker. His confrontational compositions and embodied camera movement explore a unique brand of realism and performance.

Shan he gu ren (Mountains May Depart, Jia Zhangke, 2015)

Another masterpiece from Jia who is capable of effortlessly showing us humour, pathos and human spirit. Another LFF 2015 screening.

Història de la meva mort (Story of My Death, Albert Serra, 2013)

Screened at Tate Modern London in March, this Locarno winner from 2013 took its time to arrive theatrically and on DVD this year. Serra develops an opaque aesthetic of extreme beauty within a cinema of ideas from literature and art history creating a bold and sensuality edging back and forth from transcendence to sublime farce.

Stretch and Bobbito: Radio That Changed Lives (Bobbito Garcia, 2015)

Revelatory and revisionary history of that often misrepresented modern cultural institution “’90s New York Rap”. An aural archive of the underground radio show that developed the music and the culture of what is glowingly referred to as Rap’s “Golden Age”. Strictly certified stuff screened at the LFF 2015.
